> Interesting work!

Thanks Vinod! 

> I was also curious to see how HyperN=
EAT would
> perform on this domain.  The videos of quadruped and hexapod ga=
its I
> evolved, and the paper I wrote with Prof. Risto Miikkulainen for la=
st
> year's GECCO are available here:
> 
>      http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/key=
word?modularne

I read your paper when you posted it last year. I think it =
is very
interesting work. In particular, I think it is cool that you can pr=
oduce all
of these different types of gaits. I do not get that kind of vari=
ety with
HyperNEAT, but I think that is because I am only using one fitness=
 function
(speed) and the two gaits I get reliably may simply be faster tha=
n the other
types of gaits. Why do you think you do not see a collapse down=
 to a single
fastest gait type in your work? Is it because you bias them so=
 strongly to
one type of gait (in each setup) that they cannot override tha=
t bias and
choose a faster gait? If so, that is a cool and interesting resu=
lts, so I am
merely asking out of curiosity and not as a criticism. It is g=
ood to be able
to get these systems to produce the types of gait we want in=
 addition to
simply producing fast gaits.

I wonder if I selected for certa=
in slower speeds, or if I selected for
energy efficiency, if I would get di=
fferent gaits that are more commonly
seen in nature. It would be a cool exp=
eriment to try.

Out of curiosity, how would you label these two gaits?

I =
think of this as pronk:

http://devolab.msu.edu/sites/devolab.msu.edu/files=
/HyperNEAT_medianFitness_1
.mpeg

and this as gallop:

http://devolab.msu.e=
du/sites/devolab.msu.edu/files/HyperNEAT_bestIndividual_
1.mpeg

I think it=
 looks like a gallop because to me it looks like this:

http://en.wikipedia=
.org/wiki/File:Muybridge_race_horse_animated.gif

> With only minor adjustm=
ents to your setup, you can convert your
> substrate configuration to repre=
sent non-linear oscillators.  In fact,
> you would get a configuration simi=
lar to my modular controllers by
> restricting the network inputs to just t=
he joint angles and producing
> angular velocities instead of angles as out=
puts.

Those changes alone would make them non-linear oscillators? But the =
only
change you mention is reducing the number of inputs. How would taking =
out
some of the inputs (the touch sensor, the pitch, roll, yaw and sine) ch=
ange
my system to possess non-linear oscillators? Or do you mean that there=
 are
other 'minor adjustments' that need to be made? If so, what would they=
 be?

How would you describe my system? Do I have linear-oscillators? Or
li=
near-non-oscillators? Please forgive me if these are na=EFve questions, but=

I am very interested in learning the proper terminology for this field.

>=
 HyperNEAT would then
> have to evolve the modularity that I specified by h=
and.  I think that
> would be an interesting experiment to run, and if succ=
essful would
> eliminate the need to specify the sine input.

I think I am =
missing something. Reducing the number of inputs would not
suddenly obviate=
 the need for the sine wave.

Nevertheless, I do think it would be an inter=
esting experiment to see
whether HyperNEAT can produce the gaits you obtain=
ed, but I think whether
that occurs is related to the fitness function issu=
e I raised above.

> BTW, did you find that
> the other inputs (i.e. pitch,=
 yaw, roll, and touch) were necessary to
> evolve good gaits in your experi=
ments?

For the setup in the paper, such information increased performance =
(although
I wouldn't call the extra information necessary, as the experimen=
ts without
such information still evolved coordinated gaits, just slower on=
es).

I did experiments with and without PRY (pitch, roll and yaw) and the
=
performance was better with PRY inputs. I also ran experiments with and
wit=
hout the touch information and found that the touch information helped.
Odd=
ly, and to my disappointment, I found that these results depended on
other =
aspects of the system. For example, when I used a different period for
the =
sine wave, and the gaits were thus different (e.g. much faster and more
fra=
ntic), it was no longer the case that the PRY and touch information
helped.=
 As such, the system does seem to be somewhat chaotic and therefore
general=
 statements such as "PRY inputs help" are unjustified.  I don't fully
under=
stand why that is the case, although I have some ideas.


Thanks for your q=
uestions and comments.
Jeff
